meaning: To accept something as true or real; to have confidence in the truth, existence, reliability, or value of something or someone.
etymology: The word 'believe' originates from the Old English word 'belȳfan', which means 'to have faith or confidence'. It is derived from the Proto-Germanic *ga-laubjan, which combines 'ga-' (intensive prefix) and 'laubjan' (to hold dear, love). The root is connected to the Proto-Indo-European *leubh-, meaning 'to care, desire, love'.
sentence: I believe in the power of kindness.
She couldn't believe her eyes when she saw the surprise.
As the famous quote by Walt Disney goes, 'If you can dream it, you can do it.' Believe in your dreams.

short_stories.title: The Boy Who Believed
short_stories.story: Once, there was a young boy who believed he could fly. Despite everyone telling him it was impossible, he practiced every day, jumping from small heights and flapping his arms. One day, he climbed a tall tree and jumped, believing with all his heart. Miraculously, he soared through the air, proving that belief can make the impossible possible.

short_stories.title: The Power of Belief
short_stories.story: A man lost in the desert stumbled upon an old lamp. He rubbed it, and a genie appeared, granting him one wish. The man wished for water, but the genie said, 'You must first believe it exists.' The man closed his eyes, believed deeply, and when he opened them, he found himself beside a flowing river.

poetry.title: Believe
poetry.author: Edgar A. Guest
lines: Believe in yourself and the world will be
A brighter place for you and me.
For faith can move the mightiest hill,
And make the impossible bend to your will.

poetry.title: If You Believe
poetry.author: Unknown
lines: If you believe in the beauty of dreams,
And the power of hope that gleams,
You'll find the strength to rise above,
And fill your heart with endless love.
